children.subject: ^I would agree but mostly because you say you want to be a PM eventually. My brother went down that route and he did not double major, only did one major and had a relatively low GPA (<3.0). He got a job a Google as a TPM straight out of bachelors and prior to that interned as a PM, and he seems to be doing well at his job. The thing is, he was really involved with clubs and led some student orgs. while in college. I think for a PM sort of role, they are mainly looking for experiences that you had outside of class doing management/leadership type work, since your classes in college don't really prepare you for PM stuff (whereas one could argue that the CS major does prepare you for engineering roles).

I'm a senior, but I have not gone down the DS/ML path so take my advice with a grain of salt. In my experience, doing a double major is almost useless for getting a job. Employers don't really care that you satisfied the graduation requirements for two different majors. You will get far more out of, and build a more impressive resume, by doing clubs/working. This seems especially true if you want to be a PM where you don't really learn any of those skills in school. I would recommend taking the DS classes that interest you and that seem important for your career, but don't get bogged down taking classes just to add a bullet point to your resume.

history.content: Hi, I am a CS sophomore who is planning to enter industry after graduation. I am also planning to do MBA in the future because I am interested in PM role. I am seeking for advices in terms of double majoring in DS with CS versus spending time taking decals(both technical and fun ones), doing clubs, working part-time, etc. Should I single major and secure my GPA and do other things? Or should I double in DS? What would be better in long term. I would appreciate any advices, especially from older people with industry experience! Thanks in advance.
history.subject: Data Science vs. Extra Curricular
